Author: George Leopold
Article: Agricultural automation on the farm has advanced in fits and starts. Drones have mostly turned out to be expensive toys, yielding a return on investment only for large operations. Other forms of automation may offer a faster ROI for some repetitive, labor-intensive chores like milking a herd of Holsteins or boosting crop yields. While short on forecast numbers, IDTechEx does identify 15 robot types and agricultural sectors ripe for automation. Row vegetables are a prime candidate.
